title: Exercise as you age to delay disabilities in golden years | Zee News
text:
Exercise as you age to delay disabilities in golden years By Zee Media Bureau | Last Updated: Thursday, February 9, 2017 - 16:26 0 Follow @ZeeNews 
New Delhi: Physical activity and exercise are good for everyone – young and old. Being physically active is one of the healthiest things you can do for yourself. 
Numerous studies have shown that physical activity provides many health benefits and that older adults who stay physically active can gain a lot. 
Now, a new study suggests that regular exercise can may help older adults prevent or delay disabilities that interfere with independent living. 
Based on the proven health benefits of exercise for older adults, a team of researchers carried out a study to test the theory that exercise might lower the severe mobility issues in adults. 
For the study, they enrolled 1,635 adults between the ages of 70 and 89 – high-risk group for becoming physically disabled. 
At the beginning of the study, the participants were able to walk about five city blocks (one-quarter of a mile) without assistance and were then split into two groups. 
Exercise may boost brain activity, memory in elderly 
One group was encouraged to exercise regularly, in addition to taking a daily 30-minute walk, they performed balance training and muscle strengthening exercises. 
The other group attended weekly workshops for 26 weeks, followed by monthly sessions in which they provided information about accessing the healthcare system, traveling safely, getting health screenings, and finding reliable sources for health and nutrition education. 
The workshop instructors also led the participants in five to 10 minute flexibility or stretching exercise sessions. 
The researchers gave all the participants thorough tests for disability at the beginning of the study and then at six, 12, 24, and 36 months after the study started. 
They reported that people in both groups experienced about the same level of disability after the study. 
However, people in the exercise group experienced a lower level of severe mobility problems than did people who attended the health workshops. 
If you want your grandparents to walk or climb stairs without any difficulty, encourage them to exercise regularly along with balance training. 
The results were published in the journal of the American Geriatrics Society.
